I've finished all 165 videos in the playlist. Let me just say this series is incredible and it truly makes every single new concept in math seem unimaginably easy. You'll think calculus and linear algebra are tough but by the end you'll treat them like they're 2+2=4, and it's all because of how well these videos explain them. Some other closing thoughts and information about the contents:  The 165 videos here reach up to about the second year in math university(mostly Analysis and later some cursory Vector Fields), and a lot of the latter-half lessons here lean more on the Applied Math side than Pure Math. This is probably intended and it's a good thing, considering all the related fields Dave specialises in. Meaning that the math you're going to learn in this series all have strong practical applications in Physics, Engineering, but also Computer Science, in case you wish to become a programmer. While not strictly necessary, and you can perfectly understand without, I might recommend knowing at least a bit about classical Physics once you reach the calculus lessons in math and beyond, although, if like most of the population you've went to school, you've probably had basic Physics classes and that alone is enough.  In any case, the math you learn here is going to be more or less all you need for most Physics or Engineering. Anything beyond will probably concern the very bleeding edge in contemporary math or physics, and is probably things I can't even begin to comprehend..

Impressive video. I look forward to the series.  I already tutor math and understand it very well, but I'm eager to watch this series anyway to see how you explain each thing and if I might through the experience of watching this improve myself further.  By the way, I found this by reading someone's comment on Reddit. I think it was on the Math Education sub there.  If I'm going to be just a little picky, we still need to choose some axioms in order to decide whether or not certain things will be true (for example, the Continuum Hypothesis if we want to say there's no size of infinity between the natural numbers and the reals), and Godel's Incompleteness Theorem shows that no matter how many axioms we have in a consistent system there will always be at least one trye fact which cannot be proven true.  But I suppose true math is more about the implications that any particular set of axioms would have on what's true than it is about picking just one set of axioms and saying absolutely what is and isn't true. So, my pickiness in the previous paragraph is of no massive concern.  I guess I could get into our brains possibly incorrectly understanding logic as well and therefore us not being 100% confident in our inductive experience of proving mathematical truths. But I'm just splitting hairs at that point between us knowing objective truth and that objective truth "existing" (in some sense) without us having the means to have true 100% confidence in precisely what it is.  Our human brains being imperfect could also make the very words I'm saying flawed - even these! But there's not much point in going down that route because it's not very practical for us actually living our lives here on Earth.  Um... but yeah, math. Math is cool! Eager to watch and listen! 😅

Hello, I am coming to you from the future. I am up to part 70 of this course. It's a very good course and I recommend it. Dave is very clear and concise in his explanations. Literally no wasted words, which is great. Nice manageable length of each part. Great graphics too. Get yourself an old-school exercise book and take good notes as you go, as you'll occasionally want to refer back to an old lesson, and you'll need to draw a lot of stuff, not just type. It gets progressively harder up to around part 30 and then it's a bit tough for about 15 parts. If you can last until part 47, it turns to geometry and suddenly gets MUCH easier again, and doesn't really get hard again until part 70. One drawback is that there are no workings shown for the answers to the comprehension questions, so if you get it wrong and nobody has provided the workings in the comments, there's nothing you can do, and it's quite de-motivating. There are a couple of errors and inconsistencies, particularly part 38, so you should read the top comments before spending ages getting frustrated with the comprehension questions.

Hey, I was typing on my phone before so sorry what I'm trying to say doesn't come across very clearly Mathematics is the study of what is necessarily true as a result of your axioms being true, and what is necessarily wrong as a result of our axioms being true.   I believe by you suggesting that mathematics is intrinsic to the universe you are suggesting that the universe follows our axioms, and all the things which are true or wrong according to our axioms. Do you think that we know exactly the axioms that the universe follows? If not then our maths is at least a tiny bit wrong for describing the universe perfectly, and certain things that are true in reality could be proven to be false mathematically. When this has happened in the past we've come up with new axioms to make the maths fit reality.   Also, according to Godel's incompleteness theorem, there are questions that can be asked within the axiomatic system, but can not be answered one way or the other. You can add another axiom that would make the question answerable, but by doing that you add more questions that can be asked, some of which still can't be answered. So to suggest that the universe follows mathematics, not the other way around, is to suggest that there are some things that the universe is undecided on.   Your whole argument for mathematics being  discovered and not invented seems to be that it makes sense, and that it's very effective. Well of course it makes sense and is effective, we made it to be useful and to describe very basic things around us, like counting, and we made very basic axioms such as "A straight line is the shortest distance between two points", and so on. These axioms are so basic and so obviously close to true in reality that what is true or false according to our axioms will almost always be exactly true in reality.  I'm not saying the universe doesn't follow certain patterns, what I'm saying is we invented maths to see those patterns more clearly, and that the universe doesn't follow those patterns as a result of maths.   I hope all that was a bit clearer, at least.  I don't mind that you don't agree, the thing that annoyed me is you presented mathematics being discovered and intrinsic to the universe as a fact when it's still highly debated among mathematicians with good arguments on both sides.

"A straight line is the shortest distance between two points" : This axiom is false for the universe because the universe is not continue.   The universe is "discriminated" : you can find a particule who nothing can be smaller than it.   So a Perfect platonic cercle doesn't exist in the universe because if you zoom enough you can see the  discontinuity because of Limit size of the smallest particule.

I think if you are looking strictly at geometry, then yes, you can argue that geometry is man-made, and in fact the universe does not follow Euclidian geometry as you say. I agree that if you construct a circle in the real world, if you zoom in far enough, you would see something like "pixels" with dimensions equal to the planck length. So I am not arguing that math, and especially not geometry, has a one-to-one correspondence with reality. As the other of you also mentioned Godel, we know that this has been proven to be impossible with his incompleteness theorem as you say. But an object possesses gravitational influence that propagates spherically. Molecules, by virtue of the electromagnetic force, make complex geometrical shapes. These things simply exist, so math simply exists. Calculus is a set of symbols, and differentiation/integration are man-made constructs, but they correlate with the relationship between position/velocity/acceleration, which is innate. There is math in the universe, and there is math we make up. So I don't dispute much of what you are saying, I am simply defending that there are mathematical relationships inherent in the universe that any alien species would notice and use to arrive at the same conclusions about the universe that we have. If every alien species also has calculus, then there is something about "calculus" that simply exists for anyone to find.

​ @ProfessorDaveExplains  It's very strange of you to be assertive about something that is debated by mathematicians for centuries and is still not settled at this point in time. Are maths invented or discovered? The simple answer is no one knows yet. I would understand that you knowingly decided to take a shortcut with this video, considering that it's close enough not to confuse your audience. But saying maths are what you say they are is really odd. Reading you shows you didn't spend much time documenting yourself on the topic. Your arguments are intuitive and spontaneous but they are an uneducated guess. Your arguments aren't enough to make your case, they are just a naïve take on the subject. You will see that there is no consensus at this point in time about what math "is". Definition are always partial and very different according to who you ask. For a reason. That's precisely because we know what maths are useful for, but not what maths are in the first place. A simple way to verify this is just to google and search the definition of maths. There isn't a consistent one. All definitions are partial as there always will be a branch of maths that doesn't fit the definition even though it's undoubtedly maths. Now go on youtube and type "what is math" and you'll see that all videos will just answer very differently. Many of them will digress very quickly ending up describing its usefulness, NOT its nature. And those, like you, who will try to define it will be challenged and their definitions will also be very opinionated. There is only one video which really tried to answer in a pragmatic way: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SNad3NvkgNg And if I acknowledge the effort, I must also say he is wrong because he has flaws in his reasoning too. He tried to be methodological but he couldn't prevent himself from injecting opinions in his reasoning, in a very subtle way. He concludes, for instance, that maths are deductive but he forgot that the axioms upon which are built maths are...inductive. He used the word reasoning in his definition which imply that maths are dependent of an intelligence to begin with (which isn't proven). At this point in time there is NO way one could define maths because there is something fundamental that isn't understood about maths yet. So, it's delusional to try to be accurate about something we fundamentally don't know. If there is no consensus about maths being invented or created, there can't be a consensus about its definition. Therefore your definition is as good but also as bad as any other's. As simple s that.
